repnme.cdata!: Benin - Third Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is rated as marginally
            satisfactory. Much remains to be done to improve the
            business environment and attract private investors. The
            economy is highly vulnerable to external shocks and even
            more dependent on cotton than it was before the reform
            program was initiated. Poorly implemented changes in the
            sector have compromised the 1998-99 crop year, and made more
            difficult the implementation of a reform process aimed at
            empowering producers. Poor management in the energy sector
            aggravated a power shortage in 1998, due to a drought in the
            region. Despite increased budget allocations to priority
            sectors, the delivery of essential services has not
            significantly improved. Implementation of ongoing projects
            in education, health, and transport in support of this
            objective is far behind schedule. The changes supported by
            the project are likely to be sustained. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are rated satisfactory. Lessons
            learned include the following: A two-tranche operation was
            not the most appropriate instrument in a difficult political
            environment. A series of single-tranche operations would
            have increased leverage and flexibility. Staff continuity on
            both sides contributed to a good quality dialogue, even when
            the political environment was not conducive to reform. An
            attempt should have been made to quantify the program's
            objectives, and a monitoring and evaluation system should
            have been put in place.

18155782.trustfund:
TF020039-DENMARK - BENIN SAL III,TF021426-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAM - BENIN,TF020789-THIRD STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT
            CREDIT TO REPULBIC OF BENIN
18155782.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

repnme.cdata!: Benin - Third Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            will support implementation of key accompanying measures
            designed to strengthen the supply response to the
            devaluation of the CFA franc and to consolidate refroms
            initiated since 1990. In particular, the devaluation has
            provided Benin the opportunity both to accelerate refroms
            that were constrained by the previous overvaluation - such
            as lower import tariff protection and privatization of
            previously uncompetitive enterprise - and to generate a
            great supply response from the measures taken since 1990.
            This credit will support the Government's efforts to
            maintain a substantial real depreciation through appropriate
            macroeconomic policies, assure a strong supply response to
            the devaluation, and improve the delivery of essential
            public services required for higher growth in the medium
            term. The adjustment package proposed under the operation
            consists of a an acceleration of fundamental policy reforms
            in two areas. First, the credit will support improved
            incentives for private sector development through further
            simplification and rationalization of foreign trade
            taxation, a deeper restructuring of domestic indirect and
            direct taxation, additional changes in the regulations
            governing commercial activity, investment and the labor
            market, and the public enterprise divestiture. Second, it
            will support improved management of public resources and
            delivery of public services by restructuring current
            expenditures, improving public investment programming and
            execution, and reorganizing key ministries.
